title: 110_s1276
content: The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 clarifies signature capture and retention for electronic methamphetamine precursor logbook systems under the Controlled Substances Act. It specifies requirements for sales of precursor products. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 outlines requirements for electronic signature capture and retention in logbooks for sales of precursor products under the Controlled Substances Act. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 mandates electronic signature capture and retention in logbooks for sales of precursor products under the Controlled Substances Act, ensuring each signature is clearly linked to other purchaser information. Bound paper books must include a printed sticker or unique identifier linking to electronic information, or a unique identifier written by the seller at the time of sale. The purchaser must sign a printed document containing details of the sale, including product names, quantities, purchaser's information, and sale date/time. The document must have a signature line and display a specific notice. Each signed document should be stored securely in a binder. Each signed document must be securely stored in a binder or other means of document storage immediately after the purchaser signs it. The seller records product name and quantity sold in a logbook, which can be done electronically. The logbook also includes purchaser's name, address, date, and time of sale. The seller must verify purchaser information entered in the logbook, which can be done electronically. The logbook includes a notice about the consequences of providing false information. The logbook must be maintained by the seller for a minimum of 2 years, whether the entries are written or electronic. Providing false information may result in criminal penalties under section 1001 of title 18, United States Code.
